journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Probability of failure on demand of safety systems: impact of partial test distribution

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratoire de Modélisation et Sûreté des Systèmes, Université de Technologie de Troyes, France

author-notes.corresp: Florent Brissaud, Laboratoire de Modélisation et Sûreté des Systèmes, Institut Charles Delaunay & UMR CNRS 6279 STMR, Université de Technologie de Troyes, 12 rue Marie Curie, BP 2060, 10010 Troyes, France.Email: florent.brissaud.2007@utt.fr

abstract.p: In accordance with the IEC 61508 functional safety standard, safety-related systems operating in a low demand mode need to be proof tested to reveal any ‘dangerous undetected failures’. Proof tests may be full (i.e. complete) or partial (i.e. incomplete), depending on their ability to detect all the system failures or only a part of them. Following a partial test, some failures may then be left latent until the full test, whereas after a full test (and overhaul), the system is restored to an as-good-as-new condition. A partial-test policy is defined by the efficiency of the partial tests, and the number and distribution (periodic or non-periodic) of the partial tests in the full test time interval.

Non-approximate equations are introduced for probability of failure on demand (PFD) assessment of a MooN architecture (i.e. k-out-of-n: G) systems subject to partial and full tests. Partial tests may occur at different time instants (periodic or not) until the full test. The time-dependent, average, and maximum system unavailability (PFD(t), PFDavg, and PFDmax) are investigated, and the impact of the partial test distribution on average and maximum system unavailability are analysed, according to system architecture, component failure rates, and partial test efficiency.

kwd-group.kwd: average probability of failure on demand

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: To meet a required tolerable risk arising from manufacturing, process, or transportation activities, safety-related systems are usually necessary risk reduction measures. The safety functions implemented by these systems aim to achieve or maintain a safe state for equipment under control (EUC), with respect to specific hazardous events. Owing to the critical role of the safety-related systems for health, environment, and goods, their ability to perform their designated safety functions needs to be ‘validated’. To this end, international functional safety standards have been developed, notably the IEC 615081 for the electrical/electronic/programmable electronic safety-related systems. The IEC 61508 adopts a risk-based approach to provide a general method for the specification of the safety requirements, and considers the overall system and software safety lifecycle phases. Application sector standards, including the IEC 615112 and the ANSI/ISA 84.00.013 for the safety instrumented systems used in the process industries, were then developed, based on the former.

In accordance with the IEC 61508, the safety requirements refer to the safety functions and to the associated safety integrity, which is the probability that the safety-related system performs the specified safety functions satisfactorily. The specification of the safety integrity requirements contains a safety integrity level (SIL) allocated to each safety function (based on the hazard and risk analysis, and to achieve the target tolerable risk), which corresponds to a target failure measure. For a safety function operating in a low demand mode (i.e. only performed on demand and not more than once per year), the target failure measure is specified in terms of the average probability of dangerous failure of the safety function on demand.1 In the realisation phase, the safety-related system then has to be created in accordance with the specification. To this end, the probability of (dangerous) failure on demand (PFD) to perform the safety function is computed as system un-availability. The average system unavailability (denoted PFDavg) is then assessed in a proof test interval, i.e. in the time period after which the system is restored to an as-good-as-new condition. (If such a proof test does not exist, the proof test interval can be replaced by the planned system lifetime.) The value obtained needs to be smaller than the target failure measure specified for the SIL. However, it should be noted that other requirements, including architectural constraints, have to be met for a given SIL.4 Furthermore, even though they are not used in the IEC 61508, other measures, such as the maximum system unavailability (denoted PFDmax) have often been considered as relevant for safety.5–7

The IEC 61508 gives a list of characteristics that have to be taken into account for PFD assessment: system architecture, failure rates of system components, common cause failures, coverage and intervals of the diagnostic tests performed online and automatically, effectiveness and intervals of proof tests, repair times, and random human errors. In the following, attention is focused on the proof tests, which are used to detect dangerous hidden failures in the system (i.e. dangerous failures that are undetected by online and automatic diagnostic tests). In the present article, when a proof test is 100% effective (i.e. complete and perfect) it is described as ‘full’ (e.g. functional testing) and refers to overhauls that restore the system to an as-good-as-new condition. On the other hand, the ‘partial’ tests are able to detect only certain system failures and leave others latent (or ‘dormant’). Such incomplete tests include, for example, visual inspections for detectors8 and partial stroke testing for shutdown valves.9,10 It should be noted that the IEC 61508 does not explicitly define proof tests that are not 100% effective, so the partial tests can be periodic or not. Even if partial tests are less effective, they can be preferred to full tests for several reasons.11

list-item.p: Full tests are generally physical (e.g. stimulation of sensing elements), costly, and time consuming. They may sometimes be substituted by electronic tests (e.g. electronic simulation) but these do not cover all the failures.

Full tests often imply stopping production (e.g. power supply cut by emergency shutdown, flow stop by safety valves), sometimes unacceptable for industrialists. Partial tests (e.g. quarter turn valve closure) are therefore preferred.
Some safety devices cannot be fully tested without degradation or destruction (e.g. one shot devices).
Only real condition testing can claim to be full and, in many cases, may provoke more hazards than prevention (e.g. detection of fire, toxic gas, or overpressure).

sec.p: Methods for the PFD assessment are mentioned in the IEC 61508 (which also proposes corresponding guidelines in an informative part): simplified equations, fault tree analysis, Markov models, reliability block diagrams, and Petri nets. These techniques have been discussed and compared in the literature,5,6,12,13 without considering partial tests. On the other hand, several approaches have been proposed to assess the partial test effectiveness (or ‘coverage’, ‘completeness’) based on: expert judgments,8 failure modes, effects, and diagnostic analyses (FMEDA),14 specific procedures,10 and feedback data.11 Taking into account partial tests, PFD assessment has been developed for single components (or serial systems) using approximate equations,8,10 and also for parallel systems using analytical expressions.15 Fault trees and Petri nets are more flexible and allow the inclusion of partial tests in PFD assessment for systems with more general architectures,7 as well as Markov models14,16 (using multiphase/regenerative Markov processes to deal with deterministic time intervals between tests). In addition, a constant probability of imperfect repair or test-generated failure has also been assumed in some references.8,7,14,17 Impact analyses have shown that test completeness (which refers to the proportion of system failures that are tested) has a higher impact on PFD than test correctness (which refers to test failures and may also include imperfect repairs).14 In the following, incomplete tests are considered, but not incorrect tests or imperfect repairs.

In all the above-mentioned references, the partial tests are always assumed to be periodic. To deal explicitly with non-periodic partial tests, an analytical approach is used in the present article. First, (non-approximate) equations are introduced in the section ‘Probability of failure on demand on safety systems’ for PFD assessment of safety-related systems subject to partial tests, which may occur at any time instants within a full test time interval. These expressions aim at investigating the time-dependent, average, and maximum system unavailability (denoted PFD(t), PFDavg, and PFDmax, respectively) of MooN architecture (i.e. M-out-of-N: G) systems. The impact of the partial test distribution on PFDavg and PFDmax is then analysed in ‘Impact of partial test distribution’ according to system architecture, component failure rates, and partial test efficiency.

sec.title: Probability of failure on demand of safety systems
General assumptions
sec.p: The following assumptions are made for the rest of the article.

list-item.p: The function of the system that is considered intends to achieve or maintain a safe state of an EUC in respect of a hazardous event. This is therefore a ‘safety function’ according to the IEC 61508.

The function of the system that is considered is only performed on demand, and the frequency of demand is low enough (in practice, it is commonly between 1 per 10 years to 1 per 10,000 years) to reasonably ignore the effects of these demands on the system and test policy characteristics.
The system has a MooN architecture, i.e. it is composed of N components and is able to perform its function if any M or more components (of N) are in an operating state.

All the failures taken into account yield system components in a non-operating state, and are only detected by partial or full tests (i.e. not detected by online and automatic diagnostic tests). These failures are therefore ‘dangerous undetected’ according to the IEC 61508.
The N components of the system are independent (in particular, no common cause failures are assumed) and have identical and constant failure rates.
The N components of the system are in an opera-ting state at time t0.
The partial tests are able to detect only some of the specific failures of each system component, which correspond to a certain proportion of each component failure rate.
The full tests are able to detect all the failures of each system component.
All the system components are tested together during any test (no staggered tests).

When one or several failures are detected by a partial or a full test, they are repaired immediately (i.e. the detected failures are ‘removed’). During tests and repairs, measures are performed to maintain a safe state of the EUC in such a way that any test or repair duration can be reasonably ignored in the PFD assessment.
After each full test, the system is restored to an as-good-as-new condition. PFDavg can, therefore, be assessed according to the full test time interval.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: The notation is given in Appendix 1 and illustrated in Figure 1.
A system is defined by the set {M, N, λ}, and a test policy can be either defined by the set {E, t1, t2, …, tn} or by the set {E, T1, T2, …, Tn}.

sec.title: General equations
sec.p: For each system component, a part with a failure rate equal to E ċλ is testable by any test, either partial or full, and another part with a failure rate equal to (1 – E) ċλ is only testable by the full tests. The corresponding reliability block diagram of each system component is then given in Figure 2, and the time-dependent availability of any of the system components is (see proof in Appendix 2)

caption.p: Reliability block diagram of any of the N components which compose the system.

sec.p: The time-dependent unavailability of the system is therefore (see proof in Appendix 3)
with the following time-independent sum
Some values of S(M, N, x) are reported in Table 1.

caption.p: {S(M, N, M), S(M, N, M+ 1), …, S(M, N, N)} for MooN architectures.

sec.p: Finally, the average unavailability of the system in the time interval between the (i – 1)th and the ith test, and in the full test time interval, are respectively (see proof in Appendices 4 and 5)
Approximations of equations (1) to (5) can also be found in Brissaud et al.11

These equations can also be extended to include common cause failures, for example with a β-factor by summing the contribution of independent failures (with MooN architecture) and the contribution of common cause failures (with 1oo1 architecture). In that case, the partial test efficiency can be different regarding independent and common cause failures.

sec.title: Special case: without partial test
sec.p: Without partial test, n = 1 and equations (2) and (5) become

sec.title: Special case: with periodic partial tests
sec.p: With periodic partial tests of period T0 = τ/n, Ti = T0 and ti = i ċ T0 for i = 1, …, n, and equations (2) and (5) become

sec.title: Special case: with α-test policy
sec.p: Equations (2) and (5) allow one to consider any partial test distribution defined by the n – 1 time instants of partial tests within the full test time interval. In order to parameterise the partial test distribution by a single parameter, a special case, denoted α-test policy, is used in the following. This policy determines the time instant of each ith test (i.e. ti) by the time instant of the previous test (i.e. ti–1), the total number of tests in the full test time interval (i.e. n), and the full test time interval (i.e. τ), using the following relation
with the parameter α such as α ≥ 0.

In this case, the test policy can then be simply defined by the 4-element set {E, n, τ, α}, instead of the (n + 1)-element set {E, t1, t2, …, tn} or {E, T1, T2, …, Tn}, and the parameter α determines the distribution of the partial tests as described above. First, let PFD(t)(α) and PFDavg(α) denote the time-dependent unavailability of the system and the average unavailability in the full test time interval, respectively, when an α-test policy is assumed.

According to equation (10), if α = 0.0 it is shown by recurrence that t1 = t2 = … = tn = τ, which is the equivalent to the case without partial test. Moreover, if α = 1.0 it is also shown by recurrence that Ti = ti – ti–1 = τ/n for i = 1, …, n, which is the case with periodic partial tests. PFD(t)(p) and PFDavg(p) can therefore also be denoted PFD(t)(1) and PFDavg(1), respectively. In addition, when α < 1.0, then T1 > T2 > … > Tn, that is, the time instants of the partial tests are closer to the end of the full test time interval; and when α > 1.0, then T1 < T2 < … < Tn, that is, the time instants of the partial tests are closer to the beginning of the full test time interval.

sec.title: Results for a baseline configuration
sec.p: The following analyses aim to assess the impact of the partial test distribution on the average and maximum unavailability of the system. The impact analyses are performed using the baseline configuration given in Table 2. The partial test distribution is determined by the parameter α, according to an α-test policy (cf. ‘Special case: with α-test policy’). The impact of the partial test distribution on the system unavailability is assessed by comparison with the case with periodic partial tests (i.e. case with α = 1.0). Then, the gain in terms of average unavailability (i.e. PFDavg) and maximum unavailability (i.e. PFDmax), in percentage, are respectively computed by Gavg(α) and Gmax(α) defined by

where PFDavg(p) = PFDavg(1) and PFDmax(p) = PFDmax(1) are, respectively, the average and maximum unavailability of the system in the full test time interval, assuming periodic partial tests (i.e. case with α = 1.0); and PFDavg(α) and PFDmax(α) are, respectively, the average and maximum unavailability of the system in the full test time interval, assuming a partial test distribution determined by the parameter α. The value of α that minimises PFDavg(α) (respectively PFDmax(α)), is also the value that maximises Gavg(α) (respectively Gmax(α)), and is denoted αavg* (respectively αmax*). The greater Gavg(αavg*) (respectively Gmax(αmax*)) is, the more the average (respectively the maximum) system unavailability can be proportionally reduced by a non-periodic distribution of the partial tests.

caption.p: Baseline configuration used for the impact analyses.

fn.p: These properties are modified in turn one after the other in ‘Impact of the partial test distribution on PFDavg’ and ‘Impact of the partial test distribution on PFDmax’.

sec.p: Figures 3, 4, and 5, depict PFD(t)(α), PFDavg(α), and PFDmax(α), for α = 1.000, α = αavg* = 0.756, and α = αmax* = 0.482, respectively, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2. The corresponding results for the system unavailability are reported in Table 3. For this configuration, the average system unavailability (i.e. PFDavg) can then be reduced by up to 9% by a non-periodic distribution of the partial tests. The greatest potential of improvement is, however, in the maximum system unavailability (i.e. PFDmax), which can be reduced by about 42%. It should also be noted that the optimised value of the parameter α is not the same when considering the minimisation of the average or the maximum system unavailability. Nevertheless, even if an optimal reduction of PFDmax increases PFDavg (cf. last row of Table 3), a compromise can be found to improve both the average and the maximum system unavailability (for example, when α = αavg* = 0.756, cf. middle row of Table 3).

caption.p: Time-dependent, average, and maximum system unavailability, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, and an α-test policy with the parameter α = 1.000.
Time-dependent, average, and maximum system unavailability, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, and an α-test policy with the parameter α = αavg* = 0.756.
Time-dependent, average, and maximum system unavailability, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, and an α-test policy with the parameter α = αmax* = 0.482.
System unavailability, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, and different partial tests policies determined by the parameter α.

sec.p: The two following sections analyse the impact of the partial test distribution on the average and maximum system unavailability, respectively, according to system architecture, component failure rates, and partial test efficiency.

sec.title: Impact of the partial test distribution on PFDavg
sec.p: To show how the partial test distribution has an impact on the average system unavailability when different configurations are considered, the system architecture, component failure rates, and partial test efficiency of the baseline configuration given in Table 2 are modified in turn one after the other. Figures 6, 7, and 8, depict PFDavg(α) with the parameter α from 0.00 to 1.25, assuming the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different system architectures (i.e. MooN), component failure rates (i.e. λ), and partial test efficiencies (i.e. E), respectively. According to the properties of the α-test policy (cf. ‘Special case: with α-test policy’), the average system unavailability, when no partial test is assumed, can be observed at the upper left of these Figures (i.e. for α = 0.00), and the average system unavailability when the partial tests are periodic are given for the abscissa α = 1.00. The minimum values of PFDavg(α) (obtained by α = αavg*) for each configuration reported in Figures 6, 7, and 8, are depicted by black triangles. It is then shown that the value of the parameter α that minimises PFDavg(α) (i.e. αavg*) depends on the system redundancy (i.e. N – M), slightly on the component failure rates, and significantly on the partial test efficiency (however, when E = 0.0 the partial tests are irrelevant and no optimum can therefore be found). The optimised partial tests tend to be grouped together at the end of the full test time interval (i.e. αavg* is smaller than one) according to the increase in the system redundancy, to the decrease in the component failure rates, and to the decrease in the partial test efficiency. Moreover, the use of a parameter α greater than 1.00 always implies a higher average system unavailability than the case where partial tests are periodic.

caption.p: Average system unavailability as a function of the parameter α, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different system architectures (logarithm scale).
Average system unavailability as a function of the parameter α, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different component failure rates (logarithm scale).
Average system unavailability as a function of the parameter α, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different partial test efficiencies (logarithm scale).

sec.p: The gain in terms of average system unavailability, using an optimised α-test policy compared with the case where partial tests are periodic, (i.e. Gavg(αavg*)), is given in Figure 9 for all the configurations assumed in Figures 6, 7, and 8. It is shown that the greater the system redundancy or the lower the component failure rates are (that is, the more intrinsically reliable the system is), the more the average system unavailability can be reduced (in percentage) by a non-periodic distribution of the partial tests. However, the relationship between the partial test efficiency and this gain is not monotone. In fact, when the partial test efficiency tends to 1.00 the optimised distribution of the partial tests tends to be periodic (cf. Figure 8), and when the partial test efficiency is close to 0.00 the effects of the partial tests are too small to have a significant impact on the average system unavailability.

caption.p: Gain in terms of PFDavg (in percentage), using an optimised α-test policy, compared with the case where partial tests are periodic (and according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2).

sec.title: Impact of the partial test distribution on PFDmax
sec.p: Figures 10, 11, and 12, depict PFDmax(α) with the parameter α from 0.00 to 1.25, assuming the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different system architectures (i.e. MooN), component failure rates (i.e. λ), and partial test efficiencies (i.e. E), respectively. The minimum values of PFDmax(α) (obtained by α = αmax*) for each configuration are depicted by black triangles in these Figures. It is then shown that the value of the parameter α that minimises PFDmax(α) (i.e. αmax*) is independent of the system architecture and component failure rates, but is only dependent on the partial test efficiency. In fact, if PFDmax(αmax*) is reached just before the (n – j)th test, that is, PFD(tn–j – ε)(αmax*) = PFDmax(αmax*) when ε tends to 0 with ε > 0 (hereafter noted ε → 0+), and if j verifies the following hypothesis:

caption.p: Maximum system unavailability as a function of the parameter α, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different system architectures (logarithm scale).
Maximum system unavailability as a function of the parameter α, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different component failure rates (logarithm scale).
Maximum system unavailability as a function of the parameter α, according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2, but for different partial test efficiencies (logarithm scale).

sec.p: For n ≥ 2, there is an integer j, with 0 ≤ j < n – 1, that verifies

(i.e. PFDmax(αmax*) is reached twice, just before consecutive tests: the (n – j – 1)th and the (n – j)th tests as, for example, in Figure 5 with n = 4 and j = 1) then, it is demonstrated that (see proof in Appendix 6)

In the configurations reported in Figures 10, 11, and 12, j = 1 verifies equation (13), and it then appears that the value of the parameter α that minimises PFDmax(α) (i.e. αmax*, solution of equation (14)) can be approximated by E with an error smaller than 0.02 (cf. Figure 12).

The gain in terms of maximum system unavailabi-lity, using an optimised α-test policy compared with the case where partial tests are periodic, (i.e. Gmax(αmax*)), is given in Figure 13 for all the configurations assumed in Figures 10, 11, and 12. The same observations are made as for average system unavailability (cf. ‘Impact of the partial test distribution on (PFDavg’). However, the maximum system unavailability can be reduced further (in percentage) than the average system unavailability, by a non-periodic distribution of the partial tests.

caption.p: Gain in terms of PFDmax (in percentage), using an optimised α-test policy, compared with the case where partial tests are periodic (and according to the baseline configuration given in Table 2).

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Equations have been introduced for unavailability (i.e. PFD) assessment of MooN architecture systems subject to partial and full tests. Partial tests can be periodic or not, and an α-test policy has been proposed to define a partial test distribution by a single parameter. The following results were obtained (under the assumptions given in ‘General assumptions’).

list-item.p: Both the average and the maximum system unavailability can be reduced by a non-periodic distribution of the partial tests, if the system has a MooN architecture with M < N, and if the partial test efficiency is equal to E with 0.0 < E < 1.0.

The partial test distribution that minimises the average system unavailability tends to group together the partial tests at the end of the full test time interval, according to the following factors (from the most to the least significant): the decrease in the partial test efficiency, the increase in the system redundancy (i.e. N – M), and the decrease in the component failure rates.
Given the hypothesis defined by equation (13), the α-test policy (cf. ‘Special case: with α-test policy’) that minimises the maximum system unavailability depends only on partial test efficiency.

The more intrinsically reliable (highly redundant and with low component failure rates) the system is, the more an optimised α-test policy can reduce, in percentage, the average and maximum system unavailability, compared with a case where partial tests are periodic.

sec.p: Prospects for development concern the inclusion of further system and test policy characteristics in the PFD assessment, such as common cause failures, imperfect repairs, test-generated failures, and non-simultaneous tests. In particular, the use of both non-periodic and staggered (partial and full) tests is a promising way to optimise performances of safety-related systems.

sec.title: Notation
sec.p: A(t) time-dependent availability of the system i.e. probability that the system is able to perform its function at time t

A
e (t) time-dependent availability of any of the N components which compose the system i.e. probability that the component is in an operating state at time t
E efficiency of the partial tests i.e. a proportion equal to E of each component failure rate corresponds to failures that are detected by any partial test

G
avg
(α) gain in terms of PFDavg, in percentage, using an α-test policy with parameter α, compared with the case where partial tests are periodic

G
max
(α) gain in terms of PFDmax, in percentage, using an α-test policy with parameter α, compared with the case where partial tests are periodic
M minimum number of components for the system to be able to perform its function

MooN system architecture (M-out-of-N: G system) with the two positive integers M and N such as M ≤ N i.e. the system is composed of N components and is able to perform its function if any M or more components (of N) are in an operating state
N number of components that compose the system
n total number of tests in the full test time interval, i.e. (n − 1) partial tests plus the nth test, which is full
